Award.AwardTitle: Genome and Transcriptome Based Prediction and Regulator Inference of Molecular and Whole-Plant Phenotypes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Right now, plant breeders have to wait to determine if their seedlings will mature into useful plants or not. This leads to delays and increase in costs of development of new varieties that are more productive, disease resistant and tolerant to environmental stresses. In the case of forestry, this wait can be decades-long, thus hampering tree improvement for the timber, paper and bioenergy industries. Development of new cultivars could be accelerated if there was a way to tell what useful traits a plant would have based on its DNA alone. The ability to use DNA to predict the traits of a grown plant, from its development to its productivity, remains one of the recognized grand challenges of plant biology. Even more relevant and incomplete is the understanding of the chain of events that lead from DNA to trait. A complete understanding of a plant's biological system will allow the identification of the key regulatory points that impact its traits of economic importance, while also allowing their prediction. In this project novel approaches will be developed to predict the development and the growth properties of plants, and their immediate regulators. These approaches will integrate information beyond DNA to include gene expression data, and create a more complete description and prediction of trait regulation. Tools developed here will be disseminated to the community by the release of analysis software packages, and workshops will be conducted to enhance teaching of quantitative genetics and statistical methods in predictive models to the scientific community. The project incorporates a training component focused on high-school teachers and students. High-school teachers will join the investigator laboratories to learn about real-world applications of genomics and develop curriculum with support of the University of Florida Center for Precollegiate Education and Training (CPET). Students from underrepresented groups will be trained in science through CPET's Student Science Training Program. The proposed research will also provide ample opportunities to train graduate students at the intersection between quantitative and statistical genetics, and genomics.

Genomic prediction of complex traits is a critical tool in animal and plant breeding. However, the ability to fully explain a phenotypic trait is still limited, in part because several dimensions of information are either not available or not incorporated to prediction models. In this project, genome sequence information will be used initially to predict gene expression, and gene expression of the ensemble of genes will be applied to predict whole-plant phenotypes. As a last step, genome sequence and transcriptome data will be integrated for prediction of phenotypes and their regulators. Thus, a model for prediction that incorporates multiple layers of information will serve as a tool for prediction of plant molecular properties (e.g. gene expression), as well as growth and developmental traits. This project will make use of a large Populus deltoides association population for which abundant genome, transcriptome and phenotypic resources are already available or will be developed here. Prediction tools will also be applicable to other species for which similar type of resources are available. The research methods to be applied to each aim will consist of four components: (1) detection of large-effect factors (e.g., individual or groups of variants with large regulatory effects) using single-factor regression methods, (2) development of prediction models that combine whole-genome information from large and small-effect factors, (3) biological validation of findings using genetic modification, and (4) statistical validation using an independent population. Genotypic and gene expression data will be publically available in NCBI's dbSNP and the sequence read archive/gene expression omnibus databases (www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov). Analysis packages will be deposited in the R Archive (http://cran.r-project.org/), and project details and plant resource access procedures will be described in the project web site (http://sfrc.ufl.edu/forestgenomics/Kirstlab/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the significant challenges of biology is predicting an individual's traits based solely on its genetic makeup. Addressing this challenge will have positive consequences in agriculture, the medical field, and other areas where one would like to determine in advance how a given individual will grow, behave, or respond to treatment.

This project aimed to address this challenge by developing and applying novel methods to combine multiple levels of biological information. More specifically, the project included the following goals: (1 ) to identify regions of the genome that regulate the expression of genes in wood developing tissues (xylem) in the tree species poplar (Populus deltoides); (2) create mathematical models to predict the expression of these genes; (3) expand the scope of these models to include genetic and gene expression information, to predict wood productivity and quality; and (4) use information derived from these models to infer the actual regulators of biomass properties. Finally, the project also involved a significant component of the training of breeding professionals, graduate students, high school teachers, and students in genomic sciences. Research on the prediction of traits based on genomic information is increasingly applied in agriculture and medicine. Thus, this training is critical to prepare new professionals to engage in this field.

The following specific activities and data were generated to achieve the goals of this project. (1) Sequencing of the RNA extracted from developing wood harvested from over 250 individuals (three replicates per individual) of a Populus deltoides population composed of genetically unrelated genotypes. All data is now publicly available from the National Center for Biotechnology Information Gene Expression Omnibus database (accession number GSE140232). (2) Estimation of transcript level for all genes, and their alternative splicing isoforms, for all individuals of the Populus deltoides population. (3) Estimation of standard quantitative genetic parameters, such as heritabilities, for each gene for which gene expression was quantified. This information indicates by how much the expression of each gene is determined by genetics versus the environment. (4)  Detection of loci in the genome that regulate the expression of each gene and alternative spliced isoform in the population. (5) Development of transcriptional networks that characterize the xylem transcriptome, including the identification of major hubs of expression regulation of transcriptional networks, by combining multiple levels of biological data. (6) Identification of transcriptional networks, and their regulators, that are implicated in trait variation related to biomass productivity and quality. All information generated in this project, and its major conclusions, are described in peer reviewed publications and in public databases. The location of gene expression regulatory loci and their heritability estimates are described in a peer-reviewed manuscript (doi: 10.1101/gr.261438.120) and in the DRYAD public data repository (doi.org/10.5061/dryad.12jm63xt6). Data on the alternative splicing variation detected in this population has been reported in a separate peer-reviewed manuscript (doi: 10.3389/fpls.2020.00590).   (7) Development of a statistical framework (BGAM=Bayesian Generalized Additive Model) for integrating multi-layer high dimensional inputs for analysis and prediction of phenotypes. The software packages developed as part of the funding of this project have been described in a peer-reviewed publication (doi: 10.1534/genetics.115.185181) and are deposited in a public repository (github.com/gdlc/BGLR-R/). (8) Discovery of critical genetic regulators of wood development, in particular the biosynthesis of lignin, one of the most recalcitrant components of biomass that limits the ability of using it as a source of energy. More specifically, a MYB transcription factor was found to have a major impact on the content of lignin in wood. The manipulation of this gene can lead to the production of wood with much more favorable properties to produce biofuels. (9) Development of outreach activities, including training yearly 2-4 high-school students through internships in the laboratory, high-school teachers, and several graduate students and postdoctoral associates in the intersection between quantitative and statistical genetics, and genomics. Online training workshops were also organized and widely attended by an international audience. The seminars presented in these workshops are available online (ufgi.ufl.edu/seminars-events/genomic-workshop/phenotype-workshop-archive/).
